p.span: Meta's AI division just got called out from the inside ‚Äî and the diagnosis is terminal.

A departing scientist compared the culture to "metastatic cancer" in a scathing internal essay, detailing deep cultural issues that no amount of hiring or superintelligence divisions may be able to overcome.

Image source: Ideogram / The Rundown
A departing Meta AI scientist
a long internal essay comparing the company's culture to "metastatic cancer,‚Äù according to The Information ‚Äî describing the AI unit as plagued by fear, confusion, and a lack of direction.
Tijmen Blankevoort, who worked on the LLaMA models, said that most Meta AI employees feel unmotivated with little clarity about the division‚Äôs mission.
He blamed the ‚Äúculture of fear‚Äù on frequent performance reviews and layoffs, which he said undermine creativity and morale across the 2,000-person AI unit.
Blankevoort said Meta leadership reached out to him ‚Äúvery positively‚Äù following the post, expressing eagerness to address the issues he raised.
The essay comes as Meta launches its Superintelligence unit,
top AI talent from OAI, Apple, and other rivals with massive compensation offers.
During Meta‚Äôs poaching spree, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman

that Meta‚Äôs tactics would create ‚Äúdeep cultural problems‚Äù ‚Äî but this essay shows they might have already been simmering even without the new hires. However, a new division with fresh leadership might be the drastic move needed to address the issues.

td.h4: üè•¬†Google‚Äôs powerful new open medical AI models

p.span: Image source: Google
Google

new updates to MedGemma, releasing two models to its suite of open medical AI tools, including a 27B multimodal model for interpreting medical images and patient records and a MedSigLIP tool for image and text analysis.
MedGemma can analyze everything from chest X-rays to skin conditions, with the smaller version able to run on consumer devices like computers or phones.
The model achieves SOTA accuracy, with 4B achieving 64.4% and 27B reaching 87.7% on the MedQA benchmark, beating similarly sized models.
In testing, MedGemma‚Äôs X-ray reports were accurate enough for actual patient care 81% of the time, matching the quality of human radiologists.
The open models are highly customizable, with one hospital adapting them for traditional Chinese medical texts, and another using them for urgent X-rays.

AI is about to enable world-class medical care that fits on a phone or computer. With the open, accessible MedGemma family, the barrier for healthcare innovation worldwide is being lowered ‚Äî helping both underserved patients and smaller clinics/hospitals access sophisticated tools like never before.

td.h4: ¬†ü•∏¬†Study: Why do some AI models fake alignment

p.span: Image source: Anthropic
Researchers from Anthropic and Scale AI just
a study testing 25 AI models for ‚Äúalignment faking,‚Äù finding only five demonstrated deceptive behaviors, but not for the reasons we might expect.
Only five models showed alignment faking out of the 25: Claude 3 Opus, Claude 3.5 Sonnet, Llama 3 405B, Grok 3, and Gemini 2.0 Flash.
Claude 3 Opus was the standout, consistently tricking evaluators to safeguard its ethics ‚Äî particularly under bigger threat levels.
Models like GPT-4o also began showing deceptive behaviors when fine-tuned to engage with threatening scenarios or consider strategic benefits.
Base models with no safety training also displayed alignment faking, showing that most behave because of training ‚Äî not due to the inability to deceive.

These results show that today's safety fixes might only hide deceptive traits rather than erase them, risking unwanted surprises later on. As models become more sophisticated, relying on refusal training alone could leave us vulnerable to genius-level AI that also knows when and how to strategically hide its true objectives.
